Award.AbstractNarration:
Previous studies of the Indo-Pacific region of Antarctica show that the margin of the ice sheet in this region has advanced and retreated into deep interior basins many times in the past. The apparent instability of this region makes it an important target for study in terms of understanding the future of the East Antarctic ice sheet and sea level rise. This project will study a number of processes that control the ice-shelf stability of this region, with the aim of improving projections of the rate and magnitude of future sea-level rise. This project will engage a range of students and train this next generation of scientists in the complex, interdisciplinary issue of ice-ocean interaction.

The project will integrate geophysical data collected from aircraft over three critical
sections of the East Antarctic grounding line (Totten Glacier, Denman Glacier, and
Cook Ice Shelf) with an advanced ocean model. Using Australian and French assets,
the team will collect new data around Denman Glacier and Cook Ice Shelf whereas analysis of Totten Glacier will be based on existing data. The project will assess three hypotheses to isolate the processes that drive the differences in observed grounding line thinning among these three glaciers: 1. bathymetry and large-scale ocean forcing control cavity circulation; 2. ice-shelf draft and basal morphology control cavity circulation; 3. subglacial freshwater input across the grounding line controls cavity circulation. The key outcomes of this new project will be to: 1. evaluate of ice-ocean coupling in areas of significant potential sea-level contribution; 2. relate volume changes of grounded and floating ice to regional oceanic heat transport and sub-ice shelf ocean dynamics in areas of significant potential sea-level and meridional overturning circulation impacts; and 3. improve boundary conditions to evaluate mass, heat, and freshwater budgets of East Antarctica's continental margins.

Performance_Institution.Name: University of Texas Institute for Geophysics

POR.DRECONTENT:
The East Antarctic Grounding Line Experiment (EAGLE) combines aerogeophysical survey and numerical ocean circulation modeling to evaluate the sensitivity of the major glacier outlets of the Aurora and Wilkes Subglacial basins of East Antarctica to ocean forcing. The Aurora Subglacial Basin (ASB) drains into the Sabrina and Knox coasts; the Wilkes Subglacial Basin (WSB) drains into the George V Coast. Multiple satellite altimetry time series have shown that the grounded ice along the Sabrina and Knox coasts have had the highest rates of thinning in the East Antarctic Ice Sheet (EAIS) but that glaciers along the George V Coast have been relatively stable. The overarching goals of the EAGLE project are to determine the major controls on each system, explain why they are behaving differently, and, by extension, evaluate the factors that could destabilize the WSB.  EAGLE was a collaboration between the University of Texas, the Australian Antarctic Division, the Institute for Geophysics of the Environment in France, and the Polar Research Institute of China.


Intelletual Merit: The EAGLE project successfully densified gravity and magnetics coverage in front of the Sabrina Coast, an area largely inaccessible to ships but vital for understanding Antarctica's most sensitive outlet, Totten Glacier, which drains the Aurora Suglacial Basin in the center of the region of interest. Additional constraints were added by the first deployment of Airborne eXpendable Bathythermometers (AXBTs) in Antarctic waters.   Surveys were conducted of subglacial lakes draining the grounding line of Totten Glacier. Through cooperation with China, dense surveys with gravity, magnetics , laser altimetry and radar were flown of the Shackleton Ice Shelf, the Amery Ice Shelf and the West Ice Shelf, in the western part of the region of interest.  In the closing days of the project, critical data was collected using the PRIC Basler over the George V Coast in front of Wilkes Basin, in the eastern part of the region of interest, complementing data collected immediately before the project started. Complementary remote sensing work using an unexploited archive of low resolution satellite data allowed the tracking of Totten Glacier's behavior at high temporal resolution with a long time record, allowing correlation between Totten's speed and wind driven ocean currents at long time scales, and Totten and sea ice at interannual time scales.  Observations of sub ice shelf channels at Totten and other ice shelves allowed the establishment of new processes controlling ice shelf breakup.  


Broader impacts:  This project allowed the training of several postdocs both in the US and Australia all of whom are moving toward permanent roles in polar and oceanography research.  Three graduate students received training in polar aerogeophysics, and two have moved into research and science support positions, while one continues to make great progress with her studies.  This project continued the decade long International Collaborative Exploration of the Cryosphere through Airborne Profiling (ICECAP) project, which has successfully transformed our understanding of the connections between East Antarctica's great Subglacial Basins and the Southern Ocean.  Data (including raw radar data) have been released through the Australian Antarctic Data Center and to the BedMachine project which is remapping the bedrock of Antarctica through coupled data and modeling.


Last Modified: 07/01/2019
Modified by: Duncan A Young

Images (1 of )
  • The Earth?s gravity field responds to changes in bathymetry and topography. In regions where bathymetry is hard to reach with ships (as is the case with sea ice or ice shelf covered areas), gravity can be a vital tool to find deep troughs in the ocean floor. EAGLE has been mapping these troughs.
    Duncan Young/UTIG
    Duncan A Young
    EAGLE gravity coverage of East Antarctica
  • The DC-3T Basler JKB supported UTIG/Australian deployments of the EAGLE team.
    Chad Greene
    Copyrighted
    Duncan A Young
    The AAD Balser JKB
  • Deployment of an Airborne eXpendable BathyThermometer sounde to sound the ocean to determine depth constraints for gravity inversion. EAGLE allowed for the first such deployments in Antarctic waters
    Gregory Ng/UTIG
    Duncan A Young
    EAGLE AXBT deployment
  • EAGLE allowed for training an international suite of postdocs and graduate students: Shown are Dr. Felicity McCormack (UTasmania), Dr. Lennke Jong (UTasmania), Wei Wei (UTexas), and Dr. Lucas Beem (UTexas) preparing for field safety training at Casey Station.
    Duncan Young/UTIG
    Duncan A Young
    Postdoc and student training
  • The Polar Research Institute of China provided their aircraft to the EAGLE project through a logistical negotiation with the Australian Antarctic Division.
    Duncan Young/UTIG
    Duncan A Young
    Chinese Basler Snow Eagle
  • Satellite remote sensing studies supported by this project tracking the glacier at high temporal resolution have resulted in a new understanding of the sensitivity of Totten Glacier to the pulse of the winds and the dynamics of sea ice.
    Chad Greene/UTIG
    Duncan A Young
    Totten Glacier interactions with wind from satellite images
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The East Antarctic Grounding Line Experiment (EAGLE) combines aerogeophysical survey and numerical ocean circulation modeling to evaluate the sensitivity of the major glacier outlets of the Aurora and Wilkes Subglacial basins of East Antarctica to ocean forcing. The Aurora Subglacial Basin (ASB) drains into the Sabrina and Knox coasts; the Wilkes Subglacial Basin (WSB) drains into the George V Coast. Multiple satellite altimetry time series have shown that the grounded ice along the Sabrina and Knox coasts have had the highest rates of thinning in the East Antarctic Ice Sheet (EAIS) but that glaciers along the George V Coast have been relatively stable. The overarching goals of the EAGLE project are to determine the major controls on each system, explain why they are behaving differently, and, by extension, evaluate the factors that could destabilize the WSB. EAGLE was a collaboration between the University of Texas, the Australian Antarctic Division, the Institute for Geophysics of the Environment in France, and the Polar Research Institute of China. Intelletual Merit: The EAGLE project successfully densified gravity and magnetics coverage in front of the Sabrina Coast, an area largely inaccessible to ships but vital for understanding Antarctica's most sensitive outlet, Totten Glacier, which drains the Aurora Suglacial Basin in the center of the region of interest. Additional constraints were added by the first deployment of Airborne eXpendable Bathythermometers (AXBTs) in Antarctic waters. Surveys were conducted of subglacial lakes draining the grounding line of Totten Glacier. Through cooperation with China, dense surveys with gravity, magnetics , laser altimetry and radar were flown of the Shackleton Ice Shelf, the Amery Ice Shelf and the West Ice Shelf, in the western part of the region of interest. In the closing days of the project, critical data was collected using the PRIC Basler over the George V Coast in front of Wilkes Basin, in the eastern part of the region of interest, complementing data collected immediately before the project started. Complementary remote sensing work using an unexploited archive of low resolution satellite data allowed the tracking of Totten Glacier's behavior at high temporal resolution with a long time record, allowing correlation between Totten's speed and wind driven ocean currents at long time scales, and Totten and sea ice at interannual time scales. Observations of sub ice shelf channels at Totten and other ice shelves allowed the establishment of new processes controlling ice shelf breakup. Broader impacts: This project allowed the training of several postdocs both in the US and Australia all of whom are moving toward permanent roles in polar and oceanography research. Three graduate students received training in polar aerogeophysics, and two have moved into research and science support positions, while one continues to make great progress with her studies. This project continued the decade long International Collaborative Exploration of the Cryosphere through Airborne Profiling (ICECAP) project, which has successfully transformed our understanding of the connections between East Antarctica's great Subglacial Basins and the Southern Ocean. Data (including raw radar data) have been released through the Australian Antarctic Data Center and to the BedMachine project which is remapping the bedrock of Antarctica through coupled data and modeling.
